label.text: Plant Diversity
A longleaf pine savanna (a grassland habitat dotted with trees) was cleared and replaced by a dense pine plantation consisting of loblolly pines.
After twenty years, scientists cleared some areas within the loblolly plantation, which are known as ‘fragments’. They planted longleaf pine seedlings in the fragments.
The fragments were laid out in the loblolly pine plantation as shown in the diagram below.
A middle fragment (M) of 1 hectare was surrounded by four larger fragments of 1.4 hectares each.
A cleared corridor connected the middle fragment to fragment (C).
Two fragments (W1 and W2) had cleared ‘wings’ similar to the connecting corridor but not linking to another fragment.
The final fragment (R) was a rectangle with no corridor or wings.
fragments surrounded by dense loblolly pine plantation forest
W1
unconnected winged fragment
connected fragment
C
corridor
M
middle fragment
R
unconnected rectangular fragment
W2
Once a year, the scientists recorded all the plant species present in each fragment and calculated the percentage of plant species:
gained since the previous year, known as the ‘colonisation rate’
lost since the previous year, known as the ‘extinction rate’.
They then calculated the colonisation rate difference and the extinction rate difference as follows:
colonisation rate difference = colonisation rate (CF) – colonisation rate (UF)
extinction rate difference = extinction rate (CF) – extinction rate (UF)
CF = fragments connected by a corridor
UF = all fragments not connected by a coridor
The graph below presents the colonisation rate difference and the extinction rate difference over the 16 years of the study.
Rate difference between connected and unconnected fragments (percentage)
colonisation rate difference
extinction rate difference
Time (years)

Select either ‘Yes’ or ‘No’ for each question.
compare C, W1, W2 and R to each other
compare C to W1, W2 and R combined
Do corridors influence biodiversity in the connected fragments?
yes
no
Do corridors influence biodiversity by increasing the fragment edge-to-area ratio of the fragments?
Do corridors influence biodiversity by increasing fragment area?

They then calculated the colonisation rate difference and the extinction rate difference as follows:
